feed.title: Red Butte Garden
feed.subtitle: The official website of Red Butte Garden

entry.title: Updates from Around the Garden
entry.content:
As the snow melts and the garden begins to bloom, life awakens at Red Butte. Our collections of conifers, roses, daffodils, and more are alive with the spirit of spring. The garden has never looked so good!

As our garden changes colors and forms, so has our website. We at Red Butte have worked hard to create a refreshed and streamlined way for you to access our events and information. The new site brings a modern design, enhanced functionality, and a mobile optimized experience for visitors on the go. We hope you enjoy it!

With warmer weather on our doorstep, it’s time to start planning for the 2017 Outdoor Concert Series. Tickets will be available for garden members online on Monday, April 24th at 7PM and in-person on Tuesday, April 25th. Tickets for the general public go on sale Monday, May 1st at 9AM both in-person and online. Renew or purchase a Garden-Plus Membership level or above by April 21st in order to participate in the April 24th member-only online presale.

For more information, CLICK HERE

Transform your garden by picking up some new plants at the annual Spring Plant Sale! The members-only day is May 12th while the general public day is May 13th. Here you will be able to purchase a range of indoor and outdoor plant species. Come check it out!

For more information, CLICK HERE

Finally, the new Water Conservation Garden Grand Opening is May 20th. This inspiring new space will showcase the beauty and diversity of water-wise plants. Enjoy plants of all varieties, each with unique methods of conserving water and living in a desert ecosystem.

For more information, CLICK HERE

Thank you for your dedication and passion for the garden. All of us here are excited to introduce you and your family to the beauty of nature.

If you would like to make a donation to the garden:

We’ll see you soon!

Sincerely,
Red Butte Garden and Arboretum
300 Wakara Way, Salt Lake City,
Utah, 84108
entry.summary: As the snow melts and the garden begins to bloom, life awakens at Red Butte. Our collections of conifers, roses, daffodils, and more are alive with the spirit of spring. The garden has never looked so good!

entry.title: 38th ANNUAL SPRING PLANT SALE
entry.content:
Please enter through the Amphitheatre gates. See map below.

It’s time once again to support the Garden at our annual benefit plant sale!

WHAT YOU WILL FIND: The Garden offers an impressive selection of herbs, specialty annuals, vegetables, sun and shade perennials, ornamental grasses, shrubs, conifers, roses, vines, trees, and the best selection of heirloom vegetables, native plants and water-wise plants! You'll find plants for every situation, including gifts and high-altitude gardening. Most of the plants are grown by local nurseries and many of the vegetables are grown here in our own greenhouses! This annual plant sale and fundraiser is always a great way to welcome the planting season!

We also offer a variety of organic gardening products such as fertilizers, and coco-fiber that when mixed into your garden or container soil, aids with water retention.

EXPERTS ON HAND: With our Garden staff and volunteers, there will be plenty of qualified help to answer your plant and gardening questions.

WHERE: The Red Butte Garden Amphitheatre. From the four-way stop sign at Chipeta and Wakara Way, turn left (or North) and follow the signs. Enter through the north-facing gate used for general admission during concerts.

WHAT TO BRING: If you have your own small wagon, bring it! We have a few shopping carts and plenty of cardboard plant trays.

PARKING: Parking is available in lot #75 outside the sale entrance and in lot #80 for overflow parking. To ease any inconvenience, Garden staff will operate a passenger shuttle from the sale entrance to overflow lots (see map) from 1pm Friday as long as needed. We also protect a “loading only” area near the sale entrance/checkout for loading plants after you are able to collect your vehicle. Note too that there are few handicapped parking stalls in this particular University lot.

Support the Garden and find some great plants! Plan ahead for Mother’s Day by purchasing a colorful hanging basket. See you at the sale!

CLICK HERE for a larger map.


SECTION HIGHLIGHTS:

  • Our extensive vegetable selection this year includes over 180 different varieties. This includes 60 different tomato cultivars, 32 different peppers (sweet and hot), 21 pumpkins and squash and a wide range of greens. At least 95 different vegetables are heirlooms. We will offer both an heirloom and a hybrid selection for most of the vegetables available. Quite a few of the selections will have been trialed here at the Garden, so you can try the varieties our staff and volunteers have grown and recommended. We will also have a selection of smaller cultivars that are ideal for small spaces or container gardening.

  • Nothing beats the color of flowering annuals for the summer garden! We will have a variety of colors and textures, sun and shade annuals, as well as a wide variety of succulents. And, don’t forget a hanging basket or mixed planter as a great Mother’s Day gift!

  • Don’t forget your favorite culinary, medicinal, tea, and fragrance herbs! Great fresh or preserved, we have a wide variety to grow and enjoy at home. Check out the slow-to-bolt Cilantro ‘Ole’ or the cold hardy Rosemary ‘Gorizia’. Get them and your favorite Lavender varieties before they’re gone! This year we’ll have several new varieties of Basil; like ‘Balsamic Blooms’ with gorgeous ornamental flowers! Try combinations like Chamomile, Lemon Grass and Mint in a container to stock up your tea cabinet. Save money on your grocery bill and have fun!!

  • We will have over 300 different species and cultivars of perennials, including sun loving, and shade loving. There is definitely something for every type of situation, including high elevation gardens. Check out the ‘Specialty Perennial’ section if you’re looking for something truly unique, and allow yourself plenty of time to browse!

  • Ornamental grasses add texture and movement to your garden! Often overlooked, grasses serve many functions in a garden in addition to aesthetics. Ornamental Grasses can be used as a focal point or in mass, and come in a variety of colors, textures, sizes, bloom times, and water requirements. Come choose from Bluestem, Feather Reed, Sea Oats, Silver Grass, Muhly, Moor grass and more, including selections ideal for shadier areas, such as Japanese Forest Grass and Sedges. No matter the site conditions or your personal taste we are sure to have an ornamental grass for you!

  • Groundcovers can solve many garden problems, such as steep slopes and masking tough areas with texture and color. From vigorous foliage cover like Wintercreeper and Pachysandra, to delicate flowering swathes of Blue Lithodora or Delosperma, we have a groundcover for every growing condition. Don’t forget about the eye-catching Plumbago for three-season interest!

  • Our selection of roses includes old-fashioned garden roses, modern shrub roses, miniatures and climbers. Beautiful blooms of all colors, combined with winter hardiness and disease-resistance, make lovely additions in the home landscape. All our roses are ‘own-root’, not grafted, which means although they may be small at first, your favorite rose will not revert back to a root stock variety after a harsh winter.

  • We offer a wide variety of flowering and shade trees, unique conifers, colorful shrubs and flowering vines. We also offer a variety of fruit trees, berry bushes, strawberries and rhubarb. Come with your questions and site information and let us help you select the right plant for your situation.

  • CLICK HERE for information on how to properly plant a tree, and register your new tree on http://www.slco.org/milliontrees/


    • Deciphering our plant ID cards:

    • An outline of the state of Utah means its native. Be aware that not all natives prefer low-water, Utah has many natives that require regular irrigation.

    • An orange sticker with a bee means the plant is bee friendly.

    • A green sticker with a mountain means the plant is hardy at high elevations.

    • Be sure to check water requirements listed on the ID cards, whether by text or sticker.

    Shop TWICE! Once to grab those important not-to-miss plants, and a second time to browse for overlooked treasures. And don’t forget that perfect Mother’s day gift!
entry.summary: Please enter through the Amphitheatre gates. See map below.

entry.title: TRES FROMME LECTURE
entry.content:
REGISTRATION REQUIRED

As part of the Water Conservation Garden Grand Opening events, join us at this lecture featuring the main designer of the Water Conservation Garden.

Fromme's design’s work focuses on intensely organization and site-specific public space and garden collaborations throughout the country. He brings a vast knowledge of horticulture, garden precedents, aesthetics, and design to each project.


CLICK HERE for more information about the May 20 Water Conservation Garden Grand Opening



TRES FROMME BIO

Tres Fromme is known for his expertise with facilitating team-based creative group process and input to create compelling and memorable places that invest participants in the outcomes. His designs all creatively innovate within the traditions and diverse contexts of the project. A proponent of experiential design, he choreographs relationships among people, spaces, and plants. For a decade Fromme led planning and design at Longwood Gardens in Kennett Square, Pennsylvania and recently for four years at the Atlanta Botanical Garden.

Education:
  • University of Georgia, Master of Landscape Architecture, 1996
  • University of Delaware, Honors Bachelor of Plant Science; concentration in Ornamental Horticulture Summa Cum Laude, 1993


Selected Public Garden Projects

  • Atlanta Botanical Garden Edible Garden; Garden Lights/Holiday Nights
  • Atlanta Botanical Garden Gainesville/Smithgall Woodland Gardens
  • Bok Tower Gardens Master Plan
  • Carleen Bright Arboretum Master Plan
  • Cape Fear Botanical Garden Master Plan
  • Desert Botanical Garden Desert Terraces and Portal
  • Huntsville Botanical Garden Core Master Plan
  • Longwood Gardens East Conservatory and Indoor Children’s Garden
  • Tulsa Botanic Garden Children’s Discovery Garden and Floral Terraces

entry.title: CERTIFICATE OF WESTERN HORTICULTURE OPEN HOUSE

link.title: CERTIFICATE OF WESTERN HORTICULTURE OPEN HOUSE

entry.content:
Red Butte Garden and Lifelong Learning invite you to a special open house on Earth Day, Saturday April 22.

Come learn more about the Certificate of Western Horticulture, a certificate designed to help Wasatch Front gardeners learn techniques to become more successful gardeners. Enjoy a tour of Red Butte Garden, meet fellow gardeners, instructors, and friends. Beverages and bagels provided.

REGISTRATION REQIRED
entry.summary: Red Butte Garden and Lifelong Learning invite you to a special open house on Earth Day, Saturday April 22.

entry.title: GARDEN POETRY READING
entry.content:
Celebrate spring and go on a walk through the Garden with the winners of our spring poetry contest! Throughout the month of April the Garden is hosting 11 poetry boxes, showcasing works from local poets in honor of National Poetry Month. Stroll the Garden with the poets to hear live readings and gain details about the meaning behind their words.

Authors in attendance will include:

  • Megan Olsen
  • Maya Johnson
  • Melinda Birrell
  • Sara Bybee
  • Tina Thomas
  • Pam Tucker
  • Joyce Marder
  • Christina Elizabeth
  • Carol Anderson
  • Julie Chytraus
  • Acacia Ott

REGISTRATION REQUIRED

SOLD OUT! Click Below To Be Added to Waiting List
entry.summary: Celebrate spring and go on a walk through the Garden with the winners of our spring poetry contest! Throughout the month of April the Garden is hosting 11 poetry boxes, showcasing works from local poets in honor of National Poetry Month. Stroll the Garden with the poets to hear live readings and gain details about the meaning behind their words.

entry.title: ARBOR DAY
entry.content:
There’s no better place than Red Butte Garden to celebrate Arbor Day! As Utah’s very own arboretum, we can't wait to share the wonderful world of trees. Due to the generous support of Rocky Mountain Power, join us for a fun day of activities and leave with a free tree to take home (while supplies last).

Thanks to funding in part by Salt Lake County Zoo, Arts, and Parks Program (ZAP) Arbor Day is a ZAP Free Day! Everyone enjoys free Garden admission.

Schedule of Events


Tree Giveaway - Children’s Garden, All Day

Thanks to the generous support of Rocky Mountain Power, all guests leave with a free White Fir, Abies concolor, to take home. Trees available while supplies last!



Tree Scavenger Hunt - Throughout the Garden, All Day

Red Butte Garden has an amazing collection of trees! See if you can find the ten trees we’ve highlighted for your Arbor Day visit as you explore the Garden today.



Exploration Stops - Throughout the Garden, All Day

Discover the amazing world of trees as you stroll through the Garden! Using your senses, discover the vital role leaves, trunks, roots, and seeds play in the life of a tree.



American Conifer Society Booth - Courtyard Garden, 9AM-Noon

Curious about conifers? Stop by the courtyard to meet David Olszyk of the American Conifer Society (ACS) and become an ACS member! Membership grants you exclusive access to ConiferQuarterly and all the latest conifer news.



Poster Contest Ceremony - Orangerie, 10-10:45AM

Students across the state have been busy learning about trees and creating their own posters to illustrate this year’s theme, "Trees are Terrific Storytellers of the Past!” Help us recognize this year’s contest winners at the official Utah State Arbor Day Ceremony.



Tree Planting - Rose Garden, 10:45-11:00AM

Participate in our 2017 Arbor Day tree planting! A new tree will be added to the Garden’s collection to commemorate this important holiday.



The Diversity of Deciduous Trees - Courtyard Garden, April 28 from 11:30AM-12:30PM

Stop by for a lunchtime tour with Crystal Kim, Garden Horticulturist, to explore deciduous trees in the Garden. Discover unique trees that are good candidates for your own yard and how they can lower your energy bill year round. Bring your questions and leave with a free tree to take home due to the generous support of Rocky Mountain Power.

Tour meets in the Courtyard Garden. Space limited to 20 guests.



Incredible Conifers! - Courtyard Garden, April 28 from 1-2PM

Join David Olszyk of the American Conifer Society and members of the Garden’s conifer planning committee on a tour to discuss the Garden’s amazing collection and how conifers can add interest to your winter landscape. Bring your conifer-related questions and leave with a free tree to take home due to the generous support of Rocky Mountain Power.

Tour meets in the Courtyard Garden. Space limited to 20 guests.
entry.summary: There’s no better place than Red Butte Garden to celebrate Arbor Day! As Utah’s very own arboretum, we can't wait to share the wonderful world of trees. Due to the generous support of Rocky Mountain Power, join us for a fun day of activities and leave with a free tree to take home (while supplies last).

entry.title: GARDEN POETRY WALK
entry.content:
Did you know April is National Poetry Month? Celebrate this important literary art with a stroll through the Garden to find eleven poetry boxes featuring poems written by winners of our Spring Poetry Contest.

Throughout April the Garden also hosts a special audio tour featuring recordings of our contest winners performing readings of their poems, all accessible from your cell phone.

Follow the instructions at each poetry box to access audio recordings. The audio tour is free, but normal cell phone carrier usage rates apply. Please be considerate of other Garden guests and listen to audio content through headphones or your phone’s earpiece.

Sign up to attend a Garden Poetry Reading featuring live readings from many of the poets themselves on Wednesday, April 26 from 5:30-6:30PM. CLICK HERE TO SIGN UP



Special thanks to our Garden Poetry Walk sponsors:
entry.summary: Did you know April is National Poetry Month? Celebrate this important literary art with a stroll through the Garden to find eleven poetry boxes featuring poems written by winners of our Spring Poetry Contest.

entry.title: WATER CONSERVATION GARDEN GRAND OPENING
entry.content:
Open from 9AM-9PM - Free admission for children ages 17 and under thanks to a generous donation from Sandi Behnken

Guided garden tours will be available throughout the day

The Water Conservation Garden has been designed to demonstrate that beautiful gardens need not require heavy application of water. Our intent is to present a garden so attractive that home and business owners will want to garden and landscape in this way.

This garden will bring an end to the myth that water-wise gardening can only exist in a landscape of rock and cacti. With the addition of this three-acre garden, Red Butte Garden will also add new educational programs to teach people how to create their own water-wise landscapes.

Like all our gardens, the Water Conservation Garden will evolve and change over time as young plants mature and more water-wise plants become available in the trade.


SCHEDULED EVENTS

10AM - 3PM
  • Drop in and enjoy water-wise kids crafts in Em's Sprout House in the Children's Garden
  • Explore Botany Bin Education Stations throughout the Water Conservation Garden
  • Discover Welcome Stations at each new themed area of the new garden
Noon - 1PM

Rain Dance
performance by the Wasatch Eagle Dancers

7 - 8PM

Water Conservation Garden Design & Vision Lecture
Creativity Run Dry: Designing the Red Butte Garden Water Conservation Garden
Presented by Garden Designer Tres Fromme, Principal, 3.Fromme Design

For more information and to register to attend this lecture please CLICK HERE
entry.summary: Open from 9AM-9PM - Free admission for children ages 17 and under thanks to a generous donation from Sandi Behnken

entry.title: Welcome Spring 2017!
entry.content:
What a great time of year spring is. The blanket of snow melts and reveals the buds and blossoms we all look forward to.

Yes, it's that time! Our daffodils are up and looking fantastic!

Leonard Messel Magnolia    Magnolia x stellata 'Leonard Messel'

This beauty is hard to miss as you enter the Courtyard.

Silver Bouquet Lungwort    Pulmonaria 'Silver Bouquet'

A lover of shade, this perennial is planted under the trees along the upper Floral Walk.

Royal Star Magnolia    Magnolia stellata 'Royal Star'

As you stroll down the Floral Walk, these show stoppers are sure to catch your eye.

Wisley Daffodil    Narcissus 'Wisley'

Red Butte Garden is home to more than 160 cultivars of Daffodil. How many can you count?

Browse Milkvetch    Astragalus cibarius

Why not go for a hike in the Natural Area and enjoy our native flora?

The weather is getting warmer and the days longer, why not come check out what Red Butte has to offer.

Photos by Jason W. Baker
entry.summary: What a great time of year spring is. The blanket of snow melts and reveals the buds and blossoms we all look forward to.

entry.title: Behind the Scenes
entry.content:
Here is a sneak peak of behind the scenes and inside of our Greenhouses, which is where the magic begins at Red Butte Garden.

Greenhouse

Hart's Tongue Fern    Asplenium scolopendrium

This is the underside of a fern leaf. The tiny black round specks are spores, which can be thought of as seeds of a fern, and they are what will develop into a mature plant.

Venus Slipper    Paphiopedilum sukhakulii x roebelenii

Rain Tree    Brunfelsia sp.

This tree's flowers exude a pleasant sweet scent.

Chinese Hibiscus    Hibiscus rosa-sinensis

Moth Orchid    Phalaenopsis sp.

Mexican Flame Vine    Senecio confusus

Queen's Tears   Billbergia nutans

I hope you enjoyed your sneak peak at behind the scenes of Red Butte Garden. We hope to see you soon!

Photos by, Heidi Simper
entry.summary: Here is a sneak peak of behind the scenes and inside of our Greenhouses, which is where the magic begins at Red Butte Garden.
